abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sustainable Livelihoods
            Project for Mongolia are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory, risk to the development outcome was Moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also rated as satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned included: 1) subsidized credit and credit
            delivered through non-financial institutions is not a
            sustainable approach to rural finance and innovation. The
            project design included three approaches to providing credit
            in rural areas: (i) subsidized credit under the Pastoral
            Risk Management (PRM) component; (ii) credit offered on
            commercial terms under the Micro-Finance Development Fund
            (MDF); and (iii) Revolving Loan Fund (RLFs) operated by
            local authorities. Of these three approaches, only the MDF
            approach proved viable and sustainable. The performance of
            the subsidized credit and the RLFs was weak, the former
            having low repayment rates and weak administration and the
            latter dropped from the project due to weak performance; 2)
            fostering community participation is a continuous on-going
            task that requires explicit attention and resources; and 3)
            information on project implementation and outcomes,
            increasing public awareness of the project, and a strong
            communications strategy are essential for successful
            implementation. Project implementation was occasionally held
            back by a lack of understanding of the project's
            objectives and approach. Even though a monitoring and
            evaluation system was established under the project, more
            attention could have been provided to presenting and
            disseminating information to a range of audiences, including
            the beneficiary communities, the general public and
            non-governmental organizations, Government and
            Parliamentarians and other interested parties.

717525.trustfund:
TF038953-MONGOLIA - PREPARATION OF
            SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PROJECT,TF026251-PHRD-SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Livelihoods Project
            supports the first phase of the Sustainable Livelihoods
            Program. The project will bring an effective approach to
            promoting improved, secured, and sustainable livelihood
            strategies developed, demonstrated, and validated in
            selected areas, and institutional capacity created so that
            these strategies can be replicated and scaled-up in the
            second phase of the Program. The project consists of four
            components: 1) Pastoral risk management will reduce the
            vulnerability of herders and enhance their resilience to
            drought, dzud (winter disasters), and other shocks through
            risk forecasting and contingency planning, grazing and
            pasture management, herder self-help initiatives, and hay
            and fodder enterprise development. 2) Micro-finance outreach
            will provide micro-finance services to targeted poor and
            vulnerable non-poor households and individual achieved in
            remote rural areas of the eight core aimags through the
            creation of a micro-financed development fund and the
            strengthening of revolving loan funds. 3) Local initiatives
            fund will establish effective mechanisms by which all
            members of the targeted communities can come together to
            identify their key infrastructure development needs and
            prioritize them for potential sub-project financing. 4)
            Project management will build on existing program management
            structure for project implementation.

TF038953-MONGOLIA - PREPARATION OF
            SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PROJECT,TF026251-PHRD-SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Sustainable Livelihoods Project
            : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This document sets out the Ethnic
            Minority Development Strategy (EMDS) for the implementation
            of the Sustainable Livelihoods Project, whose objective is
            to enhance capabilities of community groups, and poor,
            vulnerable households to better manage risk, build income
            generation assets, and participate in the improved community
            infrastructure, and basic services. The social assessment
            argues the project does not create conditions by which
            ethnic minorities will benefit from the development process,
            nor does any legal, or practical difference exist in the
            entitlement of, or access by different ethnic groups to
            natural resources. For this reason, rather than an
            indigenous peoples plan, this EMDS is seemingly a more
            appropriate instrument to benefit ethnic minorities. The
            EMDS is based on the legal framework of the Constitution of
            Mongolia, which stipulates the principles that all citizens
            have equal rights, and on the policies of the Bank on
            indigenous peoples. Under the Local Initiative Fund
            component, particular flexibility will be allowed for ethnic
            minorities. Areas for support will be on women's health
            to reduce the high maternal mortality rates, in particular
            among Kazakh minorities - an issue to be explored further,
            since it is contradictory to the low infant mortality rates;
            and, on education, and the medium of instruction - up to the
            secondary level, instruction is in Kazakh language, a
            conflicting issue upon accessing higher education, for the
            official prevailing, language is Mongolian. Information
            dissemination programs will be established, and, capacity
            building, and training carefully planned, and monitored.
            Summaries of the Resettlement Policy Framework, and Ethnic
            Minorities Development Strategy are included in Vol. 2.

display_title.display_title:
Mongolia - Sustainable
            Livelihoods Project : indigenous peoples plan : Ethnic
            minority participation framework

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Sustainable Livelihoods Project
            : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The report sets out the policy framework
            for compensation, resettlement, and rehabilitation of
            project affected persons (PAPs), based on the Constitution
            of Mongolia, and on the Mongolian Law on Land, which
            provides the principles, and procedures that ensure
            assistance to improve, or at least restore living standards,
            income, and productive capacity. Although by and large, no
            resettlement, nor land acquisition under the project is
            anticipated, possible small-scale infrastructure
            sub-projects may impact local communities negatively. The
            resettlement principles are as follows. Land acquisition,
            and/or involuntary resettlement will be avoided as possible,
            to minimize negative impacts on PAPs. Houses and other
            affected structures, will be compensated at replacement
            costs, with no deductions for depreciation, nor for salvaged
            materials for potential new structures. Land losses will be
            compensated in terms of land-for-land of equal agricultural
            productive capacity, or in cash at replacement costs.
            Residential land, and/or premises shall be compensated at
            equal size. Transportation, and moving assistance allowances
            will also be provided. This framework stipulates the
            entitlement policy, including full, and partial
            resettlement, and the institutional arrangements, in
            accordance with the consultations with PAPs.

            acquisition policy framework

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Sustainable Livelihoods Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Livelihoods Project
            consists of three main components: pastoral risk management
            (PRM), supporting the preparation and implementation of an
            integrated strategy to reduce herders' vulnerability to
            drought; microfinance service outreach (MSO), supporting
            structural change in commercial and civil society provision
            of microfinance services; and local initiative funds (LIF),
            supporting demand-driven mechanisms for beneficiary groups
            to select, co-finance, and execute investments in basic
            infrastructure and social services. This environmental and
            social assessment suggests that the project has the
            potential to deliver an overall positive environmental
            impact through a contribution to reduced land degradation in
            PRM. The environmental assessment has considered all of the
            potential negative impacts of the project activities and
            provides details on several activities that may have
            negative impacts and proposes mitigation actions. These
            activities include: community-based rodent control,
            community-based control of predation, community-based
            construction and rehabilitation of wells, emergency
            restocking, haymaking, intersum/inter-aimag otor reserves,
            and veterinary services. The potential of the project to
            deliver positive improvements in reduced land degradation
            should far outweigh any localized environmental impacts of
            the project activities.

Environmental and social assessment of the
            Sustainable Livelihoods Project
